title: Energy - claim about final speed of three balls

content.question: Three tracks are shaped as shown, with identical inclined sections at the beginning, and sections that extend over the same horizontal distance. Track <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mtext>A</mtext></mstyle></math> has a bump in the horizontal section, Track <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mtext>B</mtext></mstyle></math> remains flat, and Track <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mtext>C</mtext></mstyle></math> has a dip in the horizontal section, as shown in the side views. Three small, identical blocks will be released from the same height above the horizontal sections of each track. There is negligible friction between the blocks and tracks. A student predicts that all the blocks will reach the end of the tracks with the same final velocity. Which statement correctly supports this claim?

choices.label: The blocks have the same total displacement and will take the same amount of time.

The change in gravitational potential energy <math alttext="U sub g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>U</mi><mi>g</mi></msub></mstyle></math> for each block-Earth system is the same from the start of the track to the end.

At the end of the track, the final kinetic energy <math alttext="K" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>K</mi></math> is equal to the final gravitational energy <math alttext="U sub g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>U</mi><mi>g</mi></msub></mstyle></math> for each of the block-Earth systems.

The kinetic energy <math alttext="K" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>K</mi></math> of each block is always equal to the gravitational potential energy <math alttext="U sub g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>U</mi><mi>g</mi></msub></mstyle></math> for that block-Earth system.

content.answer: The change in gravitational potential energy <math alttext="U sub g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>U</mi><mi>g</mi></msub></mstyle></math> for each block-Earth system is the same from the start of the track to the end.

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
